author: By Tara Siegel Bernard
title: Interest Rates Are Low, but Loans Are Harder to Get. Here’s Why.
description: Banks have tightened standards, becoming more choosy about their borrowers and asking a lot of questions.
content: As public school teachers, Tori Smith and her husband have careers that should survive the coronavirus economy, but their mortgage lender wasn’t taking any chances.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Jesse McKinley
title: Meet the Official Accused of Helping Trump Politicize Homeland Security
description: Chad F. Wolf joined the Department of Homeland Security in its infancy to help prevent another 9/11. Now he is helping President Trump use it to achieve his political ambitions.
content: WASHINGTON — It took only 24 hours after President Trump attacked New York City in his State of the Union address for the president’s man at the Department of Homeland Security to act.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brian Seibert
title: The Vail All-Stars, San Francisco Dreaming and Black Lives Matter
description: This week’s standouts in streaming dance, plus something to get the kids involved and moving.
content: Situated in a Rocky Mountain resort town, the Vail Dance Festival has never been the most easily accessible event. But in this summer of digital or (nearly) nothing, it’s available to all, on YouTube through Aug. 15. Since this year’s four programs are mostly a selection of performances filmed in recent years, they offer a chance to discover what, apart from its alpine setting, has made the festival distinct.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Abi-Habib and Zia ur-Rehman
title: Poor and Desperate, Pakistani Hindus Accept Islam to Get By
description: Drawn by jobs or land offered by Muslim groups, some Hindus, facing discrimination and a virus-ravaged economy, are essentially converting to survive.
content: The Hindus performed the prayer rituals awkwardly in supplication to their new, single god, as they prepared to leave their many deities behind them. Their lips stumbled over Arabic phrases that, once recited, would seal their conversion to Islam. The last words uttered, the men and boys were then circumcised.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. David Goodman
title: N.Y.C. Health Commissioner Resigns After Clashes With Mayor Over Virus
description: The resignation of Dr. Oxiris Barbot, the commissioner since 2018, came after Mayor Bill de Blasio stripped her agency of a key virus-tracing program.
content: New York City’s health commissioner, Dr. Oxiris Barbot, resigned on Tuesday and voiced her “deep disappointment” with Mayor Bill de Blasio’s handling of the pandemic, renewing scrutiny of his leadership during the crisis just as the city faces pressing decisions about how quickly to reopen schools and businesses.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan K. Stack
title: Behrouz Boochani Just Wants to Be Free
description: He fled Iran’s Revolutionary Guard. He exposed Australia’s offshore detention camps — from the inside. He survived, stateless, for seven years. What’s next?
content: To hear more audio stories from publishers like The New York Times, download Audm for iPhone or Android.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard
title: Blasts Rock Beirut, Killing Dozens and Wounding Thousands
description: The cause remained unclear hours later. But officials in the Lebanese capital said 2,750 tons of highly explosive ammonium nitrate had been stored in a depot at the center of the explosion.
content: BEIRUT, Lebanon — The blasts came within seconds of each other.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: McClatchy, Family-Run News Chain, Goes to Hedge Fund in Bankruptcy Sale
description: A federal judge signed off on a $312 million deal for the prestigious newspaper company to Chatham Asset Management at a hearing Tuesday.
content: The history of the newspaper business was on vivid display at a hearing on Tuesday, when a federal bankruptcy judge confirmed the sale of the McClatchy Company, a newspaper chain run by the same family since 1857, to a New Jersey hedge fund in a deal valued at $312 million.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Caron
title: How Families Are Finding God, Grace and Faith Outside a House of Worship
description: Parents say they miss the religious communities that were a big part of their lives, but they are finding ways to practice their faith with their children.
content: In the Jacobs home, Shabbat has become synonymous with two things: Facebook Live and Shira Averbuch, the ukulele-playing, golden-voiced singer who serves as the artist-in-residence at B’nai Jeshurun, a nearly 200-year-old synagogue on the Upper West Side of Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Beatriz Miranda
title: A Black Pianist Helped Birth Bossa Nova. His Story Is Rarely Told.
description: Johnny Alf has always been revered by Antônio Carlos Jobim and João Gilberto, but his legacy remains obscure, even among Brazilians.
content: João Gilberto’s landmark “Chega de Saudade” is widely considered bossa nova’s first album. But about seven years before its 1959 release, a Brazilian musician known as Johnny Alf composed “Rapaz de Bem.” The song incorporated several elements that became hallmarks of the genre: a linear melody, a gentle way of singing, a series of unconventional key changes, a rhythmic dissociation of drums and bass.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Morgan Campbell
title: Toronto Tones Down Its Postseason Party
description: The N.H.L. playoffs are proceeding without fans in and around Scotiabank Arena, leaving hockey to compete with other leagues for attention.
content: TORONTO — On Bremner Boulevard just west of Scotiabank Arena, a few TV news crews gathered outside the temporary fence surrounding the building, hoping to see N.H.L. teams leaving or entering the perimeter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Mervosh and Manny Fernandez
title: ‘It’s Like Having No Testing’: Coronavirus Test Results Are Still Delayed
description: A shortage of chemicals needed to test for the virus is part of what is slowing turnaround times.
content: Frustrated by a nationwide testing backlog, the governors of six states took the unusual step of banding together on Tuesday to reduce the turnaround time for coronavirus test results from days to minutes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: A New Rooftop Option for Drinking and Dining at Pier 17
description: A Williamsburg spot from the team behind Eight Mile Creek, a milk tea cafe in Greenwich Village, and more restaurant news.
content: Rooftop drinking and dining has become an attractive option amid the pandemic: The venues are mostly outdoors and provide enough space for social distancing. The Pier 17 complex, part of the Howard Hughes Corporation’s development at the South Street Seaport, is a fine example of that. Surrounded by promenades with views across the East River to Brooklyn, its rooftop, open year-round, has a collection of cabana-like pods set on patches of faux lawn for dining and drinking throughout the day. There are 28 of them, each accommodating up to eight people, to be reserved in advance. They’re equipped with umbrellas, lounge chairs, coolers and USB ports, and you can order from your smartphone. The pods require reservations; two other areas, a north patio and south patio, are first-come, first-served. The menu for the entire rooftop consists of fruity cocktails, some of them slushy, and food like fish and chips, organic chicken sandwiches, and salmon and squash kebabs. On the pier’s ground level, one restaurant, Malibu Farm, will open for outdoor dining on Thursday. The Fulton by Jean-Georges Vongerichten is opening soon, along with David Chang’s Momofuku Ssam Bar, moving into the Bar Wayo space. Another restaurant on the pier, Carne Mare from Andrew Carmellini, which was supposed to make its debut in April, has yet to announce an opening date.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Parul Sehgal
title: In ‘Luster,’ a Young Woman Moves in With Her Lover — and His Family
description: Raven Leilani’s novel concerns a young Black woman who becomes involved with an older white man who is in an open marriage.
content: You may know of the hemline theory — the idea that skirt lengths fluctuate with the stock market, rising in boom times and growing longer in recessions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Hunter
title: Don’t Believe the Lie That Voting Is All You Can Do
description: Stop minimizing the work of movements.
content: The Black Lives Matter movement has had significant wins in recent months. Municipalities have removed statues of racists, corporations have changed branding that reinforced racial stereotypes, schools have cut ties with police forces and cities have reduced police funding.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Answering Your Questions About Taylor Swift’s ‘Folklore’
description: Readers asked about Bon Iver, country music, Jack Antonoff and more.
content: Taylor Swift’s “Folklore” is currently the No. 1 album in the country, earning the third-biggest weekly total for any LP in four years. (Only Swift’s previous two albums had higher numbers.) It marks a new approach for the singer and songwriter: announced on short notice, made in relative isolation, experimenting with avant-pop production styles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matt Richtel
title: Forget Spas and Bars. Hotels Tout Housekeeping to Lure Back Travelers.
description: Hilton has partnered with Lysol, Four Seasons with Johns Hopkins Medicine. But new research shows hotels can be easily contaminated by the coronavirus.
content: When Beau Phillips checked into a hotel near Toledo recently, a table in front of the counter barricaded him from getting too close to the clerk, who wore a mask and stood behind a plastic window.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Derrick Bryson Taylor
title: F.D.A. Adds More Hand Sanitizers to List of Products to Avoid
description: The agency has moved to keep several of the products, which it found to have inadequate concentrations of alcohol, from entering the United States.
content: The Food and Drug Administration has expanded its list of hand sanitizers that consumers should avoid to include products with inadequate levels of alcohol in addition to those containing methanol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elliot Haspel
title: Why Are Child Care Programs Open When Schools Are Not?
description: Society’s perception of child care being of lesser quality to education has rarely been so pronounced.
content: Although school buildings in Philadelphia will remain closed this fall, St. Mary’s Nursery School, a secular child care center founded in 1964, will remain open. St. Mary’s, which serves children ages 18 months to 12 years, typifies an odd juxtaposition:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katherine J. Wu
title: Scientists Uncover Biological Signatures of the Worst Covid-19 Cases
description: Studies of patients with severe cases of Covid-19 show the immune system lacks its usual coordinated response.
content: Scientists are beginning to untangle one of the most complex biological mysteries of the coronavirus pandemic: Why do some people get severely sick, whereas others quickly recover?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Randall Munroe
title: How Hot Is Too Hot?
description: The human body can survive at surprisingly high temperatures, so long as you’re prepared to sweat.
content: “What is the hottest ‘room’ temperature at which a human body can, by sweating, keep itself cool enough to avoid health damage?”
source.name: The New York Times

title: Is the U.S. Ready to Vote by Mail?
description: What we’ve learned from the very different experiences of two states, Georgia and Montana.
content: Listen and subscribe to our podcast from your mobile device:Via Apple Podcasts | Via Spotify | Via Stitcher
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stacey Steinberg
title: Why Parents Should Pause Before Oversharing Online
description: As social media comes of age, will we regret all the information we revealed about our families during its early years?
content: As a mother of three, a photographer and a children’s rights lawyer, my roles as memory keeper and memory revealer are constantly in flux.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonah Engel Bromwich and Ezra Marcus
title: The Anonymous Professor Who Wasn’t
description: A professor at Arizona State University does not exist.
content: An anonymous anthropology professor remained outspoken about fairness in academia even as she suffered for months with coronavirus.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Flavelle and Henry Fountain
title: Hurricane, Fire, Covid-19: Disasters Expose the Hard Reality of Climate Change
description: Twin emergencies on two coasts this week — Hurricane Isaias and the Apple Fire — offer a preview of life in a warming world and the steady danger of overlapping disasters.
content: A low-grade hurricane that is slowly scraping along the East Coast. A wildfire in California that has led to evacuation orders for 8,000 people. And in both places, as well as everywhere between, a pandemic that keeps worsening.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: New York Needs Less Bickering, More Teamwork
description: Residents are nervous and exhausted. It’s not too much to ask for a unified leadership from the mayor and the governor.
content: Gov. Andrew Cuomo and Mayor Bill de Blasio have before them some of the most difficult challenges any holder of their respective offices has ever faced. Both men are often forced to choose between the least worst of many bad options. So, you’d think this great crisis would be an opportunity for the mayor and the governor to set aside their long-running feud and work together. The prognosis isn’t great.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Wines and Richard Fausset
title: With Census Count Finishing Early, Fears of a Skewed Tally Rise
description: With 60 million households still uncounted, the bureau said it would wrap up the survey a month early. Critics called it a bald move to politicize the count in favor of Republicans.
content: WASHINGTON — With the Trump administration’s decision to end the 2020 census count four weeks early, the Census Bureau now has to accomplish what officials have said it cannot do: accurately count the nation’s hardest-to-reach residents — nearly four of every 10 households — in just six weeks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman and Neil Vigdor
title: Trump Assesses John Lewis’s Legacy: ‘He Didn’t Come to My Inauguration’
description: President Trump was asked by an interviewer to reflect on the late congressman’s contributions to the civil rights movement. He talked up his own record instead.
content: President Trump played down the accomplishments of Representative John Lewis, the recently deceased civil rights icon, and criticized him for not attending the Trump inauguration in an interview conducted while Mr. Lewis was lying in state at the Capitol.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Pam Belluck
title: When Covid Subsided, Israel Reopened Its Schools. It Didn’t Go Well.
description: As countries consider back-to-school strategies for the fall, a coronavirus outbreak at a Jerusalem high school offers a cautionary tale.
content: JERUSALEM — As the United States and other countries anxiously consider how to reopen schools, Israel, one of the first countries to do so, illustrates the dangers of moving too precipitously.
source.name: The New York Times

title: How Trump’s Upbringing Molded His Personality
description: Readers respond to an article about how empathy was a sign of weakness in the Trump family and to revelations by the president’s niece.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Jacobs
title: Turmoil After a Museum Deletes ‘Black Lives Matter’ From Postings
description: The director of the Seattle Children’s Museum faced a strike and an internal inquiry after she edited staff postings, citing fund-raising and other concerns.
content: In the wake of the police killing of George Floyd and the protests that followed, institutions of every kind worked to figure out what they wanted to say.

title: ‘The Animals Are Dying. Soon We Will Be Alone Here.’
description: In “Migrations,” Charlotte McConaghy’s visceral reimagining of “Moby-Dick,” a young woman documents some of the world’s last surviving seabirds.
content: MIGRATIONSBy Charlotte McConaghy

author: By Troy Closson
title: How the Tropical Storm Is Affecting New York
description: The storm could bring two to four inches of rain across the region, with coastal flooding and strong wind likely throughout Tuesday.
content: [Want to get New York Today by email? Here’s the sign-up.]

author: By Nina Burleigh
title: The Caribbean Dilemma
description: Many islands are open to American travelers. Going could mean bringing coronavirus to places ill prepared to deal with it. Not going could mean deepening economic woes. How do you choose?
content: Last year, more than 31 million people visited the Caribbean, more than half of them from the United States. I was one of them. Together, we contributed $59 billion to the region’s 2019 gross domestic product — accounting for a whopping 50 to 90 percent of the G.D.P. for most of the countries, according to the International Monetary Fund.
source.name: The New York Times

description: Here’s what you need to know.

author: By Stanley Reed
title: BP to step up renewable investment as it reports a huge loss.
description: BP reported a $16.8 billion quarterly loss on Tuesday, and cut its dividend in half for the first time since the Deepwater Horizon disaster a decade ago, as lower oil prices and plunging demand from the effects of the coronavirus pandemic took a toll on the London-based energy giant.
content: BP reported a $16.8 billion quarterly loss on Tuesday, and cut its dividend in half for the first time since the Deepwater Horizon disaster a decade ago, as lower oil prices and plunging demand from the effects of the coronavirus pandemic took a toll on the London-based energy giant.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: The Chicago Fed president says it’s up to Congress to save the economy.
description: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago said the central bank had limited room to do more and that Congress would need to support the economy if the United States faced a full-fledged second wave of coronavirus infections.
content: The president of the Federal Reserve Bank of Chicago said the central bank had limited room to do more and that Congress would need to support the economy if the United States faced a full-fledged second wave of coronavirus infections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Nagourney and Jennifer Medina
title: From Outsider to Insider: Karen Bass’s Unexpected Journey to Power
description: At every step in her political career, the California congresswoman had to be coaxed to run for a higher office. Now she’s a top contender to be Joe Biden’s running mate.
content: LOS ANGELES — In 2008, as California confronted its most severe fiscal crisis since the Great Depression, the center of power in the state capital was a tent. It was set up in the courtyard outside the office of Gov. Arnold Schwarzenegger, an invitation-only retreat with folding chairs, a fake grass floor and ashtrays. Mr. Schwarzenegger, his aides and California’s most influential players — mostly white men — went there to smoke expensive cigars and talk politics and legislative deals.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Where Clothing May Come Apart
description: Jacob Stulberg has had it.
content: TUESDAY PUZZLE — Oh, come on! What the heck, Jacob Stulberg?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Trish Bendix
title: Seth Meyers: After TikTok, Trump Could Ban Candy Crush
description: “I’m almost certain Trump has no idea what TikTok is. I’m betting TikTok was one of the answers he wrote on his cognitive test,” Seth Meyers joked on Monday’s “Late Night.”
content: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous night’s highlights that lets you sleep — and lets us get paid to watch comedy. We’re all stuck at home at the moment, so here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Looking for Miss America’ Tells the History of the Legendary Pageant
description: The new book by Margot Mifflin shows how the famous contest for women reflected conflicting ideas about female beauty, ambition and fame over the past 100 years.

description: The coronavirus relief debate has Republicans falling back into pre-Trump grooves.

author: By Patrícia Campos Mello
title: Brazil’s Troll Army Moves Into the Streets
description: President Jair Bolsonaro and his allies have seeded online hatred against the institutions that defend democracy. Now the outrage is spilling beyond the internet.

title: Coronavirus Live Updates: McConnell Signals Openness to Jobless Aid Extension
description: Tens of millions of Americans have lost crucial jobless benefits, and lawmakers still can’t seem to agree on a relief measure. Israel’s troubled school reopenings could be a lesson for the U.S.
content: Negotiators on Capitol Hill reported little progress on Tuesday toward reaching an agreement over an economic recovery package. But the top Senate Republican signaled that he might be willing to reverse course and accept the extension of $600-per-week jobless-aid payments that many in his party oppose if it would yield a compromise, and the White House and congressional Democrats agreed to an end-of-the-week deadline to seal a deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Aimee Ortiz
title: Lawsuit Demands Sign Language at White House Virus Briefings
description: The lack of American Sign Language interpreters at coronavirus briefings violates the First Amendment, the National Association of the Deaf says.
content: The National Association of the Deaf and five deaf Americans have sued the White House, arguing that the lack of a sign language interpreter at President Trump’s coronavirus briefings violates the First Amendment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff
title: More U.S. Troops Will Leave Afghanistan Before the Election, Trump Says
description: The president’s assertion undercuts diplomats who have said withdrawals will depend on the Taliban’s commitment to its peace deal with the United States.
content: President Trump said that there would be fewer than 5,000 American troops in Afghanistan by Election Day in November, signaling that the United States would continue to withdraw troops from the country despite limited progress toward the start of peace negotiations between the Afghan government and the Taliban.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Appeals Court Blocks Immigrant Wealth Test in the Northeast
description: The federal court ruled that the Trump administration’s so-called public charge rule for green card applicants could not go into effect in New York, Connecticut and Vermont.
content: WASHINGTON — A federal appeals court on Tuesday blocked the Trump administration’s efforts to deny permanent residency to legal immigrants who make even limited use of public benefits like Medicaid, food stamps or housing vouchers, but restricted the injunction to New York, Connecticut and Vermont.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesse McKinley
title: Disputed Ballots Must Be Counted in N.Y. Congressional Race, U.S. Judge Rules
description: Delays continue in a race that remains undecided six weeks after a Democratic primary in which Representative Carolyn B. Maloney faced off against a challenger.
content: A federal judge in Manhattan ruled late Monday that at least 1,000 disputed ballots in a closely watched Democratic congressional primary should be counted, upending a race that remains undecided six weeks after the election and that has drawn the attention of President Trump and embarrassed the New York City Board of Elections.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Turkewitz
title: Colombia Supreme Court Orders Ex-President Álvaro Uribe Detained
description: A decision to put Mr. Uribe under house arrest as a fraud and bribery investigation unfolds could be a turning point in a nation used to seeing powerful politicians avoid prosecution.
content: BOGOTÁ, Colombia — Colombia’s Supreme Court ordered on Tuesday the detention of a former president and longtime giant of Colombian politics, Álvaro Uribe, amid an investigation into whether he committed acts of fraud, bribery and witness tampering.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Henry Fountain
title: Why Hurricanes Bring Tornadoes After They Make Landfall
description: Tornadoes start in the outer edges of hurricanes. Once a storm is over land, the increase in surface friction can lead to twisters.
content: As Hurricane Isaias worked its way through the Mid-Atlantic states Tuesday, its winds steadily diminishing, a new hazard arose: tornadoes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah
title: Massachusetts Court Won’t Use Term ‘Grandfathering,’ Citing Its Racist Origins
description: The practice was “adopted by some states after the Civil War in an effort to disenfranchise African-American voters,” the court noted.
content: A wine organization announced in June that it would no longer use the term “master” to refer to its high-ranking experts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William Langewiesche
title: The Reporter Who Told the World About the Bomb
description: “Fallout,” by Lesley M.M. Blume, recounts how John Hersey revealed the devastating toll of the atomic bomb on the citizens of Hiroshima.
content: FALLOUTThe Hiroshima Cover-Up and the Reporter Who Revealed It to the WorldBy Lesley M. M. Blume

author: By Niraj Chokshi
title: F.A.A. says Boeing has ‘effectively mitigated’ defects in the 737 Max.
description: The Federal Aviation Administration on Monday proposed changes that Boeing must make to the 737 Max, potentially clearing the way for the plane to start flying again by the end of the year.
content: The Federal Aviation Administration on Monday proposed changes that Boeing must make to the 737 Max, potentially clearing the way for the plane to start flying again by the end of the year.

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Google faces an E.U. investigation into its Fitbit acquisition.
description: European Union authorities on Tuesday announced an investigation of Google’s $2.1 billion purchase of the fitness-tracking company Fitbit, raising alarms about the health data the internet giant would be acquiring as part of the deal.
content: European Union authorities on Tuesday announced an investigation of Google’s $2.1 billion purchase of the fitness-tracking company Fitbit, raising alarms about the health data the internet giant would be acquiring as part of the deal.

author: By James Gleick
title: This Is How It All Ends

content: THE END OF EVERYTHING(Astrophysically Speaking)By Katie Mack
source.name: The New York Times

author: By A.O. Scott
title: ‘An American Pickle’ Review: Keeping It Kosher
description: A time-travel farce plays as a Jewish joke about an old-world immigrant and his millennial great-grandson, both played by Seth Rogen.
content: “An American Pickle,” a time-travel farce directed by Brandon Trost and adapted from a New Yorker story by Simon Rich, marinates crisp almost-timeliness in the mild brine of nostalgia. It’s not too salty or too sour, and it’s neither self-consciously artisanal nor aggressively, weirdly authentic. The subject, more or less, is what it means to be Jewish, and given how contentious that topic can become — can I get an oy vey? — the movie finds an agreeable, occasionally touching vein of humor.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: Some caterers are finding creative ways to keep their businesses afloat.
description: Caterers say they are taking a financial beating, with some expecting their business to be down between 80 and 90 percent this year. But many feel better situated than those in the restaurant business. Instead of paying often expensive rent in desirable locations like most restaurants, caterers typically pay less for large kitchens that can be off the beaten track.
content: Caterers say they are taking a financial beating, with some expecting their business to be down between 80 and 90 percent this year. But many feel better situated than those in the restaurant business. Instead of paying often expensive rent in desirable locations like most restaurants, caterers typically pay less for large kitchens that can be off the beaten track.

title: ‘Wandering in Strange Lands,’ by Morgan Jerkins: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Wandering in Strange Lands,” by Morgan Jerkins
content: In 1869 the Gullah Geechee people owned half of Beaufort County of South Carolina. Since then, they’ve lost fourteen million acres. The best example of the rapid marginalization of Gullah Geechee people is on Hilton Head Island, one of the most lucrative places in the South.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tucker Malarkey
title: Through the Russian Wilderness in Search of the World’s Largest Owl
description: In “Owls of the Eastern Ice,” Jonathan Slaght recounts his quest to track down the elusive Blakiston’s fish owl, a journey that will push him to the edge of endurance.
content: OWLS OF THE EASTERN ICEA Quest to Find and Save the World’s Largest OwlBy Jonathan C. Slaght
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Abdi Latif Dahir
title: Tanzania’s President Says Country Is Virus Free. Others Warn of Disaster
description: Tanzania hasn’t reported a single coronavirus case in three months, even as the African continent is expected this week to cross the threshold of one million reported cases.
content: NAIROBI, Kenya — More than 88 days have passed since Tanzania reported even a single new coronavirus case — far longer than any other African country. Tanzania’s president has declared the scourge “absolutely finished” and encouraged tourists to come back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ian Prasad Philbrick and Sanam Yar
title: Miles Apart on Coronavirus Relief
description: And what else you need to know today.
content: Democrats and Republicans in Congress started far apart on negotiations over the latest coronavirus stimulus bill last month. They haven’t closed the gap much since — even though extended unemployment benefits expired Friday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mimi Swartz
title: The Story of Refugees in America Through the Gripping Tales of Two Women
description: In “After the Last Border,” Jessica Goudeau offers a searing history of this nation’s response to humanitarian crises while recounting the stories of two refugees.
content: AFTER THE LAST BORDER Two Families and the Story of Refuge in AmericaBy Jessica Goudeau
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Distilleries rushed into the hand sanitizer market. Now some are trying to get out.
description: More than 800 craft distillers across the United States leapt into action to help in the first wave of the pandemic by producing hand sanitizer, urged on by federal agencies. But with demand for sanitizer fluctuating, distillers have faced unforeseen costs and excess supplies that they could not get rid of.
content: More than 800 craft distillers across the United States leapt into action to help in the first wave of the pandemic by producing hand sanitizer, urged on by federal agencies. But with demand for sanitizer fluctuating, distillers have faced unforeseen costs and excess supplies that they could not get rid of.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kathryn Shattuck
title: Robert Battle Keeps Going With Sarah Vaughan and Homegrown Tomatoes
description: The Alvin Ailey artistic director is hunkered down in Connecticut, tending his vegetable garden and keeping his mood aloft with these 10 essentials.
content: “I always say that pessimism and anger is a place that I visit, but my permanent address is optimism and hope,” said Robert Battle, the artistic director of Alvin Ailey American Dance Theater. And this year he’s done plenty of traveling back and forth.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Isaias Reaches Canada as a Dwindling Storm
description: At least two people were killed after a tornado touched down in Bertie County, N.C., and two others in the United States were killed by falling trees.
content: Isaias pounded a large swath of the Atlantic Coast on Tuesday, unleashing heavy rains and winds as fast as 70 miles per hour as it swept through the Carolinas and into the Northeast.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Gaia Pianigiani
title: Italy Leaders Hail Genoa’s New Bridge as Sign of Resilience
description: Less than two years after the collapse of the Morandi Bridge killed 43 people and embarrassed the nation, Italy inaugurated its replacement, and vowed to do better.
content: Less than two years after the collapse of a highway bridge in Genoa took 43 lives and became a source of national embarrassment, Italy’s leaders flocked to the city on Monday to inaugurate a gleaming replacement that they called proof of the country’s resilience and prowess.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: What Do America’s Racial Problems Have in Common With India and Nazi Germany?
description: In “Caste,” the journalist Isabel Wilkerson looks to other countries’ histories to show how our racial order is founded on a hierarchal structure of hereditary status.
content: CASTE The Origins of Our DiscontentsBy Isabel Wilkerson
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Edgar Sandoval
title: ‘Like a Horror Movie’: A Small Border Hospital Battles the Coronavirus
description: The hospital in Starr County, Texas, had no I.C.U. at all, and only one doctor on duty for each shift. Then the coronavirus began surging through the Rio Grande Valley.
content: RIO GRANDE CITY, Texas — A tense rescue scene has been unfolding for weeks outside a small rural hospital on the Mexican border that has been the first line of defense against one of the most voracious coronavirus outbreaks in the country.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Bret Stephens
title: The Siren Song of ‘One State’
description: A hopeless plan could dash hopes for a peaceful resolution between Israelis and Palestinians.
content: Amos Oz, the Israeli writer who was also a founder of the Peace Now movement, was once asked by a Norwegian journalist why Jews and Palestinians couldn’t just live as equal citizens in a single state. Oz countered by asking why Norway and Sweden couldn’t just merge into a single state, too, as they had been for most of the 19th century.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dorie Chevlen
title: 5 Things You Need to Upgrade Your Tiny Outdoor Space
description: It’s never been more important to make your balcony, terrace, or patch of cement cozy and hospitable. Here’s how.
content: Growing up in a squat ranch house in Ohio, I dreamed of moving to the Big City (any big city) and serenading dewy-eyed writer boys on a ukulele from my very own urban veranda. Now that I work at Wirecutter and live in New York — which is cramped under the best circumstances, let alone during a pandemic — I’ve found that wandering into my small outdoor space has many more benefits, helping to alleviate the boxed-in feeling I get from waking, working, relaxing and sleeping under one roof. It’s a restlessness people are experiencing no matter where they live during this summer of quarantine.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniela J. Lamas
title: ‘If I Hadn’t Been Transferred, I Would Have Died’
description: Conversations about death from Covid-19 revolve around patient characteristics. But hospitals matter, too.
content: There she was. After more than three weeks on the ventilator, after battling weakness and delirium on the general medical floor and a stay at the long-term rehab hospital where she rebuilt the strength to walk again, my patient had made it home. The dark shadows beneath her eyes were fading. Her skin was tanned. The persistent shortness of breath had finally abated, and she had recently run four miles to commemorate four months since she was diagnosed with Covid-19.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kim Brooks
title: A New Mother Chronicles Her Journey to Hell and Back
description: In “Inferno,” Catherine Cho writes honestly of surviving postpartum psychosis.
content: By the time Andrea Yates drowned her children, she believed that Satan was inside her, and that the only way to protect her daughter and four sons from a similar fate was to kill them and send them to paradise. In the wake of Yates’s trial — and in the trials of other women who hurt or neglect their children during bouts of postpartum psychosis — coverage has tended to dwell on the least useful question: How could any sane woman kill her kids? A better question, and the one explored in Catherine Cho’s captivating first book, “Inferno,” would inquire about the factors (biological, cultural and environmental) that make some women vulnerable to episodes of acute, severe mental illness in the period after they become mothers.
source.name: The New York Times

title: BlackRock, on Argentina’s Debt Accord
description: The firm says its role is consistent with its commitment to stakeholder capitalism. Also: Transgender service members; a paucity of conversation; second-home owners.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Talmon Joseph Smith
title: Inaction and a Blame Game in the Throes of a Calamity
description: Federal relief has ended, and the need grows worse.
content: This article is part of the Debatable newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it on Tuesdays and Thursdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Kenigsberg
title: ‘Red Penguins’ Review: A Rowdy Look at Post-Soviet Russia
description: This new documentary tells the tale of the Americans who invested in Russia’s premier hockey team in the early 1990s. Unsurprisingly, things went awry.
content: The director Gabe Polsky’s “Red Penguins” qualifies as a follow-up of sorts to his 2014 documentary “Red Army,” titled after a nickname for the Soviet Union’s near-indomitable national hockey team. But this time, sports are almost incidental.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma
title: Trump Appointee With History of Anti-L.G.B.T.Q. Remarks Leaves Aid Agency
description: Merritt Corrigan, the former deputy White House liaison for the U.S. Agency for International Development, had drawn scrutiny shortly after being named to the position.
content: WASHINGTON — A Trump administration appointee whose anti-L.G.B.T.Q. comments had spurred calls for her removal has left the United States Agency for International Development, an agency spokeswoman said on Monday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Daniel Kraus
title: What if the Meat We Ate Was Human?
description: Agustina Bazterrica’s dystopian second novel, “Tender Is the Flesh,” uses cannibalism to highlight the inhumanity of factory farming.
content: TENDER IS THE FLESH By Agustina Bazterrica Translated by Sarah Moses
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Giovanni Russonello
title: A Wider-Than-Thought Trump Investigation
description: New York prosecutors may be circling the president’s business practices: This is your morning tip sheet.
content: Fauci has Birx’s back, Obama endorses over 100 down-ballot candidates, and the Manhattan D.A. may be taking a harder look at Trump. It’s Tuesday, and this is your politics tip sheet. Sign up here to get On Politics in your inbox every weekday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford’s chief Jim Hackett to retire as company tries to regain momentum.
description: Ford Motor said its chief executive, Jim Hackett, will retire on Oct. 1, ending a three-year run in which the automaker has worked with mixed results to streamline its operations and focus its business on electric cars, trucks and sport-utility vehicles.
content: Ford Motor said its chief executive, Jim Hackett, will retire on Oct. 1, ending a three-year run in which the automaker has worked with mixed results to streamline its operations and focus its business on electric cars, trucks and sport-utility vehicles.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Greg Bensinger
title: Is Microsoft Sure It Wants to Buy TikTok?
description: Running a social media service brings headaches and scrutiny.
content: Microsoft has emerged in recent days as the leading suitor for the fast-growing but embattled social media app TikTok. What the company may be buying is a big headache.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Eligon
title: Distrust of the Minneapolis Police, and Also the Effort to Defund Them
description: Residents on Minneapolis’s North Side, which has a majority Black population, have mixed opinions on the City Council’s effort to significantly reduce the police force.
content: MINNEAPOLIS — The burgundy Oldsmobile sped through an intersection in a tree-lined residential neighborhood on Minneapolis’s North Side, and Lisa Williams shook her head in disgust.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pranshu Verma and Vivian Yee
title: Trump’s Syria Sanctions ‘Cannot Solve the Problem,’ Critics Say
description: Without a broader diplomatic effort, the newest and toughest penalties will worsen a humanitarian crisis without forcing a leadership change, experts say.
content: WASHINGTON — The Trump administration has embarked on its toughest round of economic sanctions against Syria, intending to break President Bashar al-Assad’s reign over the country and stop a civil war that has claimed over half a million lives.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Summer Reading Contest Winner, Week 6: On ‘The Phantom Handbag’
description: Thank you to the teenagers who participated this week, and congratulations to our winner, Hexuan (Judy) Wang, as well as our many runners-up and honorable mentions.
content: Thank you to the 1,204 teenagers who participated in the sixth week of our 10-week Summer Reading Contest, and congratulations to Hexuan (Judy) Wang, our winner, as well as to our many runners-up and honorable mentions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tim Wu
title: What Years of Emails and Texts Reveal About Your Friendly Tech Companies
description: Theatrics distracted from the real payoff of the congressional hearings: the subpoenaed documents.
content: The spectacle of the chief executives of Amazon, Apple, Facebook and Google’s parent testifying before Congress last week made for good TV drama. Yet the theatrics of the showdown distracted from the real payoff of the hearings: the accompanying cache of subpoenaed emails and texts from the past decade and a half. These documents provide compelling evidence — long rumored but seldom established — that the companies, especially Facebook and Amazon, in their rise to dominance did not always play by the rules and apparently violated antitrust laws.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Bird
title: Edmund White’s High-Octane Saga of Twin Sisters and 1950s Texas
description: White’s new novel, “A Saint From Texas,” traces the fates of Yvonne — who marries a French nobleman — and Yvette, who becomes a nun.
content: A SAINT FROM TEXASBy Edmund White
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julia Carmel
title: The Rockettes’ ‘Christmas Spectacular’ Is Canceled
description: MSG Entertainment, which owns Radio City Music Hall and manages the Rockettes, cited the uncertainty of the coronavirus.
content: For the first time in 87 years, the show at Radio City Music Hall won’t go on, the owner of the venue said Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jason Zinoman
title: Sam Jay: A Comic Who Belongs to No Camp
description: With a deadpan glare, the stand-up takes shots at everyone and won’t say something funny just for a laugh. Now she’s on the cusp of breaking out, thanks to a Netflix special.
content: The stand-up comic Sam Jay calls herself a late bloomer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: New & Noteworthy Audiobooks, From Covid Parenting to Didion Onstage
description: A selection of recent audiobooks of note; plus, a peek at what our colleagues around the newsroom are reading.
content: YES, I CAN SAY THAT: When They Come for the Comedians, We Are All in Trouble, by Judy Gold, read by the author. (HarperAudio.) The veteran humorist defends comedy and its creators, from Samantha Bee to Nimesh Patel to Michelle Wolf, against all who would censor them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Ford, Struggling in a Changing Industry, Replaces Its C.E.O.
description: Jim Hackett, who failed to impress Wall Street, will be replaced by James Farley, an auto industry veteran who started his career at Toyota.
content: Three years ago, Ford Motor brought in a new chief executive, Jim Hackett, to streamline the company’s inner workings and raise profits.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Joanne Kaufman
title: Harris Faulkner, Working From Home in Shades of Blue
description: The Fox News anchor’s mother gave her some decorating advice: ‘Just make it beautiful.’ And she’s been trying.
content: When Harris Faulkner stands on the roof deck of her family’s townhouse in Edgewater, N.J., she has a fine view of the Hudson River agleam in the sun, the George Washington Bridge off to the left and the ferry as it pulls away from the terminal and heads for the Far West Side of Manhattan.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alan Feuer
title: The Mayor Blames the Virus for Shootings. Here’s What Crime Data Shows.
description: Mr. de Blasio has pointed to court delays and bail reform to explain the surge in gun violence. But the N.Y.P.D.’s own numbers tell a different story.
content: In the past few weeks, Mayor Bill de Blasio and his police commissioner, Dermot F. Shea, have tied the steep rise in shootings in New York City to a breakdown in the criminal justice system that they contend has allowed criminals back out on the streets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Charlie Warzel
title: How QAnon Creates a Dangerous Alternate Reality
description: Game designer Adrian Hon says the conspiracy theory parallels the immersive worlds of alternate reality games.
content: In 2019, the F.B.I. cited QAnon as one of the dangerous conspiracy theories posing domestic terrorist threats to the United States and cited past incitements of violence from its adherents. Despite its fringe origins, the conspiracy movement continues to grow in troubling ways. QAnon-supporting candidates are running for office in surprising numbers (Media Matters’ Alex Kaplan reports that “at least 14 candidates made it out of primaries to the ballot in November or to primary runoffs.”) The movement has been tacitly embraced by President Trump and his re-election campaign, who’ve amplified QAnon accounts and even some of their memes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Megan Specia
title: L.A. Mansion Party That Defied Pandemic Ban Ends in Deadly Shooting
description: Five people were injured, one of whom later died, at a large gathering in violation of coronavirus restrictions at a multimillion-dollar hillside home near Beverly Hills.
content: What began as a party that drew a large group of people to a mansion on the famed Mulholland Drive in Los Angeles devolved into chaos and gunfire in the early hours of Tuesday morning, leaving five people wounded, one of whom later died, the authorities said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nick Corasaniti
title: Decoding the Trump Ad Buy
description: After going dark on the TV airwaves last week, the Trump campaign has returned, targeting early voting states.
content: Hi. Welcome to On Politics, your guide to the day in national politics. I’m Nick Corasaniti, your host on Tuesdays for our coverage of all things media and messaging.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Annie Karni
title: Trump Signs Landmark Land Conservation Bill
description: The bipartisan Great American Outdoors Act guarantees funding for federal land use efforts. The president claimed credit for Republicans.
content: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Tuesday signed into law the Great American Outdoors Act, a measure with broad bipartisan support that guarantees maximum annual funding for a federal program to acquire and preserve land for public use.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ed Simon
title: We Need a Monument to the Unknown America
description: A memorial makes a statement about who is worth preserving. Why not a sacred and beautiful nothingness?
content: In Rome’s Palatine Museum, built atop the excavation site of Emperor Domitian’s palace and not far from imperial residences of Tiberius and Augustus, there is a curious bit of masonry that was rediscovered in 1820. This artifact is exhibited alongside terra cotta heads of Jupiter and marble sculptures of Apollo, all of the grand detritus of a lost civilization housed in a former monastery. At the corner of one of the museum’s galleries sits this short altar chiseled from granite that’s slightly worn from the elements and framed with a modest curled design where a statue might sit. No idol is framed by the base; no statue of strong Jupiter or beautiful Apollo sits atop the altar. It is rather simply dedicated to Agnostos Theos — the “Unknown God.” Where a deity would normally be present is rather a sacred and beautiful nothingness.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Margaret Lyons
title: After ‘The Good Fight,’ Try ‘The Split’
description: Our television critic answers your questions and offers guidance on what to watch next.
content: What comes after “The Good Fight”? — Douglas
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily Cochrane and Nicholas Fandos
title: Trading Concessions on Recovery Plan, Negotiators Set Week’s End Deadline for a Deal
description: White House officials and top Democrats reported some movement in their talks on a pandemic relief package as the talks reached a crisis point on Capitol Hill.
content: WASHINGTON — The White House and congressional Democrats on Tuesday crept toward an elusive compromise on an economic recovery plan, agreeing to an end-of-the-week deadline to seal a deal that would restore expired jobless aid for tens of millions of Americans even as they remained far apart on the contours of the package.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Victoria Shannon and Hiroko Masuike
title: Vaccine, Beirut, Census: Your Tuesday Evening Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Davey Alba and Brian X. Chen
title: Apple Replaces Phil Schiller as Its Top Marketing Executive
description: Mr. Schiller will be replaced by Greg Joswiak, a longtime executive at the company.
content: Apple announced on Tuesday that its long-serving chief marketing officer, Phil Schiller, would step down and be replaced by Greg Joswiak, a prominent product marketing executive at the company.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Zimmer and Katie Thomas
title: Scientists Are Optimistic About New Vaccine Studies From Novavax
description: The company has received a $1.6 billion grant from the government’s Operation Warp Speed to have 100 million doses ready by early 2021.
content: Novavax, the little-known Maryland company that received a $1.6 billion deal from the federal government for its experimental coronavirus vaccine, announced encouraging results in two preliminary studies on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shira Ovide
title: When Taming Big Tech Goes Wrong
description: What the United States can learn from Europe’s efforts to restrain America’s tech giants.
content: This article is part of the On Tech newsletter. You can sign up here to receive it weekdays.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tina Rosenberg
title: Using Telemedicine to Treat Opioid Addiction
description: Getting medication long meant seeing a licensed provider. Now a strategy for evading Covid-19 makes treatment available via the web.
content: Covid-19 has made life much harder for people with opioid addiction. But the response to the virus has also revealed a way forward that could radically expand effective treatment and reduce overdose deaths.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Leland
title: Helen Jones Woods, Member of an All-Female Jazz Group, Dies at 96
description: She played trombone in the multiracial International Sweethearts of Rhythm, but later put down her horn forever. She died of the coronavirus.
content: This obituary is part of a series about people who have died in the coronavirus pandemic. Read about others here.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elian Peltier
title: 3 Men Marooned in the Pacific Are Rescued After Writing SOS in the Sand
description: Three days after their boat ran out of fuel and drifted off course in Micronesia, the men were found in good condition after a plane saw their giant plea for help spelled out on the sand.
content: Here’s a useful tip: If you ever find yourself stuck on an uninhabited island in the Pacific, it turns out that writing SOS in giant letters on the sand works.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alyson Krueger
title: Weddings as a Coronavirus Super-Spreader Worry
description: Despite precautions, the coronavirus has swept through a number of weddings, large and small, infecting guests and vendors.
content: Jo Ellen Chism, 57, a retiree who lives in The Woodlands, Texas, about an hour outside Houston, was nervous about attending her stepson’s wedding on June 20.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By J. Kenji López-Alt
title: A Colombian Chef Shares His Secret to Better Empanadas
description: For even better flavor and texture in his masa, J. Kenji López-Alt borrowed a technique from the chef Carlos Gaviria: milling popcorn.
content: I showed up at the chef Carlos Gaviria’s apartment in Bogotá, Colombia, fully expecting to bite into something surprisingly delicious, but I did not expect to have my mind blown.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Prevost
title: For Robots, It’s a Time to Shine (and Maybe Disinfect)
description: The pandemic has turned cleaning and other mundane building tasks into a challenge, stoking interest in machines as cost-effective solutions.
content: The Neo is a four-foot-tall, 1,000-pound robot floor scrubber. The high-tech machine can cruise large commercial buildings on its own, with no human supervision required.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Who the Heck Is That?
description: A look at one of the entries from last week’s puzzles that stumped our solvers.
content: Last week’s Friday puzzle by Claire Rimkus and Erik Agard included a move named after the Olympic gold medalist Simone BILES, the most decorated gymnast in history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabella Kwai
title: TikTok, Spain’s Monarchy, Turkey: Your Tuesday Briefing
description: Here’s what you need to know.
content: (Want to get this briefing by email? Here’s the sign-up.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Malia Wollan
title: How to Keep a Condor Wild
description: Faced with such a strange big bird, you might find yourself nervously talking baby talk. Don’t do that.
content: “Don’t treat condors as pets,” says Tiana Williams-Claussen, director of the Yurok Tribe Wildlife Department. Scavengers with a nine-and-a-half-foot wingspan, condors are sacred in Yurok cosmology, but it has been more than 100 years since they soared over the tribe’s ancestral territory, in northwestern California. Next spring, Williams-Claussen and her team, along with state and federal government partners, hope to release six juvenile birds born in captivity. Creatures not raised in the wild often need time to learn and practice how to exist without human help. “Let them engage in natural behaviors without being influenced by humans too close by,” Williams-Claussen says.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jamelle Bouie
title: Trump Doesn’t Need the Most Votes. What if He Doesn’t Even Want Them?
description: Government of the minority, chosen by a minority, on behalf of a minority, is not what Lincoln had in mind at Gettysburg.
content: Nearly everyone involved in reporting on, analyzing or forecasting the upcoming presidential election agrees that Donald Trump could win another term in office. But no one save his most dedicated sycophants thinks he could do so with a majority of the public on his side. We have accepted, as a matter of course, that Trump could be constitutionally re-elected through the Electoral College, but not democratically selected by the voting public.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kellen Browning
title: Distilleries Raced to Make Hand Sanitizer for the Pandemic. No Longer.
description: Even though coronavirus cases have surged again, craft distilleries say the business of making the disinfectant has become more difficult.
content: As the coronavirus pandemic shuttered bars and restaurants in March, Phil McDaniel’s craft distillery in St. Augustine, Fla., stopped producing bourbon. Then he realized there was one alcohol-based product he could make that people would still clamor for: hand sanitizer.
source.name: The New York Times

title: What to Watch For in Today’s Primaries
description: Representative Rashida Tlaib faces a rematch in Michigan. And some Republicans aren’t thrilled about Kris Kobach’s Senate campaign in Kansas.
content: This briefing has ended. Read our coverage of Kris Kobach’s loss in Kansas, and follow live election results.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Katie Thomas and Noah Weiland
title: As Trump Praises Plasma, Researchers Struggle to Finish Critical Studies
description: Thousands of Covid-19 patients have been treated with blood plasma outside of rigorous clinical trials — hampering research that would have shown whether the therapy worked.
content: An American Airlines flight took off from La Guardia Airport in New York last Wednesday morning, carrying 100 pouches of blood plasma donated by Covid-19 survivors for delivery to Rio de Janeiro. American scientists are hoping Covid-19 patients in Brazil will help them answer a century-old question: Can this golden serum, loaded with antibodies against a pathogen, actually heal the sick?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Damien Cave
title: What Lockdown 2.0 Looks Like: Harsher Rules, Deeper Confusion
description: Melbourne, Australia’s second-largest city, is becoming a case study in handling a second wave of infections. There are lots of unanswered questions.
content: Australia’s second-largest city, Melbourne, is grappling with a spiraling coronavirus outbreak that has led to a lockdown with some of the toughest restrictions in the world — offering a preview of what many urban dwellers elsewhere could confront in coming weeks and months.
source.name: The New York Times

title: ‘Life of a Klansman,’ by Edward Ball: An Excerpt
description: An excerpt from “Life of a Klansman,” by Edward Ball
content: The middle of the week is good for an attack, for the surprise. It is March 4, 1873, in the city of New Orleans, a Tuesday night. About 9:00 p.m., a man called Polycarp Constant Lecorgne emerges from his house by the levee of the Mississippi River. He is a forty-one-year-old carpenter. Constant Lecorgne and his wife, Gabrielle Duchemin, live in a neighborhood called Bouligny. They have six children, and Gabrielle is pregnant with another. Gabrielle and the children remain in the house when Constant leaves for the night. He carries a gun, probably a revolver. The U.S. Army confiscated most of the long guns years ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brooks Barnes
title: Disney, Staggered by Pandemic, Sees a Streaming Boom
description: The company lost $4.7 billion in the latest quarter, but also reported that Disney+ has about 60.5 million subscribers after nine months of operation.
content: The Walt Disney Company reported doomsday financial results on Tuesday as a result of the coronavirus pandemic and a television-related write-down, with net quarterly losses totaling $4.72 billion.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Corrections: Aug. 4, 2020
description: Corrections that appeared in print on Monday, Aug. 4, 2020.
content: An article on Monday about the teenager who recently hacked Twitter misattributed a quote to Colby Meeds and referred incorrectly to his relationship with Graham Ivan Clark. Referring to Mr. Clark, Mr. Meeds said, “He scammed me for a little bit of money when I was just a kid,” not that Mr. Clark “would do anything for money.” Also, Mr. Meeds was a fellow player of Minecraft, not a friend of Mr. Clark’s.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Eshe Nelson and Daniel Politi
title: Argentina secures a deal to restructure $65 billion in debt.
description: After months of negotiations, Argentina has reached a deal with its creditors, including the asset managers BlackRock and Greylock Capital Management, to restructure about $65 billion in foreign debt, the economy ministry said on Tuesday.
content: After months of negotiations, Argentina has reached a deal with its creditors, including the asset managers BlackRock and Greylock Capital Management, to restructure about $65 billion in foreign debt, the economy ministry said on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Herrman
title: The New Panic Buys: Kayaks, Pools, Tents and Trampolines
description: Americans seeking getaways (or staycations) in the pandemic are putting outdoor retailers in a supply crunch.
content: In January, the Outdoor Foundation, the nonprofit arm of the Outdoor Industry Association, shared some gloomy statistics. According to its annual survey, fewer than 20 percent of Americans were recreating outside at least once a week, working out to an estimated billion fewer outdoor activities a year compared to a decade earlier. Just under half of the population, the organization estimated, was not participating in outdoor recreation at all.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mark Landler
title: New Nominations to U.K. House of Lords Raise Old Concerns of Cronyism
description: Critics say Prime Minister Boris Johnson’s nominations for lifetime legislative posts continued a pattern of patronage that undermines the credibility of a long-troubled institution.
content: LONDON — One is a Russian-born British newspaper baron whose father was once a K.G.B. officer. Another is a retired cricket player who goes by the nickname Beefy, and yet another is the prime minister’s younger brother.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: The Lebanon Explosions in Photos
description: Images from Beirut show the extent of the devastation from blasts that shook the Lebanese capital on Tuesday.
content: The two explosions that ripped through Beirut, Lebanon’s capital, on Tuesday evening killed more than 100 people and wounded thousands of others. The second, much larger blast devastated a wide area, knocking people down, overturning cars and enveloping much of the central city in dust and smoke. Windows miles away were blown out, leaving streets looking like they had been “cobbled in glass,” according to a resident.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mihir Zaveri and Ed Shanahan
title: 2.5 Million Lose Power and One Is Killed as Isaias Batters N.Y. Area
description: The storm that tore through New York City on Tuesday was second only to Hurricane Sandy in knocking out service to Con Edison customers.
content: More than two and a half million customers lost power and at least one person was killed after Tropical Storm Isaias tore through New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on Tuesday, battering the region with heavy rain, tornadoes and nearly hurricane-force winds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Siobhan Roberts
title: How to Think Like an Epidemiologist
description: Don’t worry, a little Bayesian analysis won’t hurt you.
content: There is a statistician’s rejoinder — sometimes offered as wry criticism, sometimes as honest advice — that could hardly be a better motto for our times: “Update your priors!”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elizabeth Kolbert
title: A History of Hurricanes in America and the Devastation They Have Wrought
description: In “A Furious Sky,” Eric Jay Dolin recounts 500 years of reckoning with the monster storms that come in off the Atlantic Ocean.
content: A FURIOUS SKYThe Five-Hundred-Year History of America’s HurricanesBy Eric Jay Dolin
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Clarey
title: Rafael Nadal Won’t Chase a Repeat of His U.S. Open Title
description: Nadal said he would prefer not to travel to the New York tournament during the coronavirus pandemic.
content: Rafael Nadal will not defend his United States Open men’s singles title.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jackie Snow
title: Clickety Clack, Press-On Nails Are Back
description: The onetime ’80s mass-market cheapie has gotten an artisanal upgrade — just in time for quarantine home manicures.
content: Yewande Moore used to get an acrylic overlay with a gel-polish manicure every couple of weeks before coronavirus hit. But when Ohio, where she lives in Athens, shut down salons, she went to Walmart to get tools to take her nails off, not knowing when she could get them done again.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lauren Messman
title: What’s on TV Tuesday: ‘John Lewis: Celebrating a Hero’ and a Timely Documentary
description: Celebrities come together to honor the congressman. And “The Stand: How One Gesture Shook the World” revisits an iconic image from the 1968 Summer Olympics.
content: JOHN LEWIS: CELEBRATING A HERO 10 p.m. on CBS. On Thursday, Representative John Lewis, who died on July 17, was eulogized by three former presidents at the Ebenezer Baptist Church in Atlanta. Lewis, a luminary of the civil rights movement, represented the city in Congress for more than three decades, following his years as an activist working alongside the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. In a continued celebration of his legacy, Oprah Winfrey, Tyler Perry, Gayle King and Brad Pitt will host this one-hour special that looks back at Lewis’s tireless civil rights work and political career, featuring appearances by Common, Jennifer Hudson, John Legend, Trevor Noah, Billy Porter and more.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: Executions Less Likely When Victims Are Black
description: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, August 4, 2020.
content: “It’s not necessarily that the death penalty has a race problem. It’s more that the United States has a race problem that happens to infect the death penalty.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jill Cowan
title: Could a Californian Be Vice President?
description: Tuesday: Yes, and here’s what it would mean for the Golden State. Also: California’s coronavirus data is slightly encouraging.
content: Good morning.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Satariano
title: Google Faces European Inquiry Into Fitbit Acquisition
description: Authorities are investigating how Google will use health and wellness data collected from Fitbit’s fitness tracking devices.
content: LONDON — European Union authorities on Tuesday announced an investigation into Google’s $2.1 billion purchase of the fitness-tracking company Fitbit, raising alarms about the health data the internet giant would be acquiring as part of the deal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kwame Anthony Appiah
title: Is It OK That I Haven’t Told My Parents I Was Fired?
description: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on why it can be hard to tell family you’ve lost your job, whether to collect unemployment benefits and more.
content: Last year I was abruptly let go from my job. I ramped up my side business, which was fine except that now the pandemic has caused an immediate decline — and potential future decrease — in business because my clients cannot quickly adapt to technology to allow for work to continue. My clients requested that I reschedule work until the fall of this year; they think that is when business will return to pre-crisis levels. (This is an industrywide issue as well.)
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rose
title: Will Superblue Be the ‘Infinity Room’ Writ Large?
description: Art objects are a bore. People want multisensory “experiences,” the more immersive the better. With JR, James Turrell,  teamLab and more, a new business venture funded by Marc Glimcher and Laurene Powell Jobs hopes to deliver.
content: You could say the whole thing started with an argument over whether to sell tickets.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Azi Paybarah and Alex Traub
title: 3 Hot Air Balloons in Wyoming Crash Into Ground
description: “You didn’t know when it was going to stop,” said one passenger.
content: For 45 minutes, Clinton Phillips and his family soared in a hot-air balloon Monday morning, high above Jackson Hole, a bucolic mountain valley in Wyoming that is popular with tourists.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Editorial Board
title: No Relief Bill, No Vacation
description: Millions of Americans can’t wait while the Senate takes the rest of the summer off.
content: On Friday, Congress effectively pushed millions of Americans off a financial cliff when it failed to extend the enhanced unemployment benefits put in place in March to soften the economic pain of the coronavirus pandemic. Millions of Americans are also in imminent danger of losing their homes as federal moratoriums on evictions expire.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jennifer Finney Boylan
title: The Doggiest Days of Summer Demand Gin and Tonics
description: They’re refreshing and ridiculously easy to make, and come with just enough bitterness to help you get through this miserable year.
content: They’re called the dog days, this stretch of July and August, because now is when Sirius, the Dog Star, returns to the night sky. The dies caniculares are said to bring about bad luck, lethargy and thunderstorms. Not to mention, you know: cataclysmic national dysfunction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Hubbard and Maria Abi-Habib
title: What We Know About the Explosions in Beirut, Lebanon
description: Dozens are dead and thousands hurt. The cause is unclear but the government said “highly explosive materials” had been stored at the blast scene in the Lebanese capital.
content: Lebanon’s health ministry said that at least 78 people had died and 4,000 suffered injuries in the explosions and fire that shook Beirut on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: W.N.B.A. Players Escalate Protest of Anti-B.L.M. Team Owner
description: Led by the members of the Atlanta Dream, players have begun wearing T-shirts supporting a political opponent of Senator Kelly Loeffler, who co-owns the Dream and has spoken against the Black Lives Matter movement.
content: Players for the Atlanta Dream and other teams across the W.N.B.A. have begun a public show of defiance by wearing T-shirts endorsing the Democratic opponent of the Dream’s co-owner Senator Kelly Loeffler, Republican of Georgia, who is in a tightly contested race for her seat and has spoken disparagingly of the Black Lives Matter movement.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alexis Schaitkin
title: A Troubled Artist’s Death Proves as Unknowable as Her Life
description: In “The Book of Atlantis Black,” Betsy Bonner attempts to solve the mysterious fate of her troubled, enigmatic older sister.
content: THE BOOK OF ATLANTIS BLACK The Search for a Sister Gone Missing By Betsy Bonner
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Orner
title: He’s Losing His Mind. Maybe His Country Is Too?
description: The protagonist of “The Tunnel,” by the Israeli novelist A.B. Yehoshua, tries to carry on after a dementia diagnosis.
content: THE TUNNELBy A. B. Yehoshua
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Stanley Reed
title: BP Reports a Huge Loss and Vows to Increase Renewable Investment
description: The European oil giant has plans for a future with more electrical generation.
content: BP reported a $16.8 billion quarterly loss on Tuesday, and cut its dividend in half — the first reduction since the Deepwater Horizon disaster a decade ago.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Walter Isaacson
title: ‘Life of a Klansman’ Tells Ugly Truths About America, Past and Present
description: In his latest book, Edward Ball retraces an ancestor’s involvement with the Ku Klux Klan in order to shed light on the country’s legacy of white supremacy.
content: LIFE OF A KLANSMAN A Family History in White Supremacy By Edward Ball
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sarah Kliff
title: How Ballot Initiatives Changed the Game on Medicaid Expansion
description: Missouri is the latest state where a nonprofit has helped put the issue before voters, bypassing Republican officials. And the vote is today.
content: It was the middle of 2016, and Obamacare supporters were stuck.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sophia June
title: Recent Commercial Real Estate Transactions
description: Recent commercial real estate transactions in New York.
content: $26.5 MILLION
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Julie Creswell
title: ‘Closing Isn’t Even an Option’: With No Events, Caterers Rush to Adjust
description: The pandemic has devastated the industry. But some entrepreneurs are finding creative ways to keep their businesses afloat.
content: On a recent Saturday, petite lobster rolls on toasted brioche and coconut shrimp with mango aioli were to be passed among the guests at a 210-person wedding. A bar mitzvah party for 180 was going to conclude with torched s’mores and a chocolate fountain.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Tiny Love Stories: ‘I Almost Left Him Three Times’
description: Modern Love in miniature, featuring reader-submitted stories of no more than 100 words.
content: I can’t help but notice the increasing frequency of Isabella singing “Wee-woo, wee-woo!” It took me a moment to realize that my 19-month-old was imitating the sounds of ambulances as they passed. We’ve become accustomed to them screaming down the streets toward Tucson Medical Center. Isabella now sings the ambulance song four, five, six times a day. Spinning with both arms raised, she projects unmitigated toddler joy at those loud, flashy boxes that roll by day and night. Every unlucky person transported past our home gets an ambulance song dedicated to them. I hope it helps. — Amber Gates
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Venutolo-Mantovani and Rick Rojas
title: Isaias Unleashes Floods and Tornadoes as It Pummels the Atlantic Coast
description: Officials warned residents to stay out of harm’s way as at least two people were killed by tornadoes, and two others from fallen trees. Millions were left without power.
content: WINDSOR, N.C. — Isaias pounded the Atlantic Coast on Tuesday with ferocious wind and driving rain, flooding communities, knocking out power for millions and spawning a series of tornadoes along its path.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Wolfe and Lara Takenaga
title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
description: A vaccine maker backed by the U.S. government is making progress.
content: Novavax, the little-known Maryland company that received $1.6 billion from the federal government to produce an experimental coronavirus vaccine, announced encouraging results in two preliminary studies on Tuesday.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christin Drake
title: The Shadow Behind Black Mothers and Their Sons
description: A Black mother describes her many hopes for her child, and all come tinged with a nagging dread.
content: My son is 4 years old. He is funny and charming and naughty in the most delightful ways possible. He is the perfect host, making sure we understand and enjoy every part of his world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tejal Rao
title: Twilight of the Imperial Chef
description: For decades, the notion of the lone genius in the kitchen has fostered culinary creativity — and restaurants marred by abuse and unfairness. This may be the time for change.
content: Picture a great restaurant, the chef up at dawn, dusting hand-milled flour on a butcher’s block. The chef under a spotlight, tweezing chive blossoms in the chaos of the pass, or fanning the wood fire under a row of shimmering, trussed birds.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Cynthia McKelvey
title: The Challenges of Polyamorous Parenting
description: Starting a family with more than two parents can present legal and social pitfalls. Here’s how some parents are making it work.
content: Policymakers in the United States are just beginning to expand their definitions of what makes a family, as the city of Somerville, Mass., passed an ordinance in June giving polyamorous groups rights that are typically only given to two-parent couples, like the ability to share health insurance. Somerville’s City Council president said that he felt the ordinance was urgent because of the pandemic, as it would allow more residents health care coverage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Live Analysis: August 4 Election Results
description: Follow live coverage and analysis from Times reporters.
content: Follow live coverage and analysis from Times reporters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Stein
title: Life Inside the N.B.A. Bubble
description: Marc Stein has covered the N.B.A. for nearly 30 years, so he’s seen a lot. But covering the league under quarantine conditions is a new experience. Here are things you’ll only see inside the “N.B.A. bubble.”
content: Marc Stein has covered the N.B.A. for nearly 30 years, so he’s seen a lot. But covering the league under quarantine conditions is a new experience. Here are things you’ll only see inside the “N.B.A. bubble.”

title: Video Shows Plane Spotting SOS Signal From Stranded Sailors
description: Three sailors drew SOS in the sand after their boat drifted off course among the hundreds of islands of Micronesia. Their decision saved their lives.
content: Three sailors drew SOS in the sand after their boat drifted off course among the hundreds of islands of Micronesia. Their decision saved their lives.

title: Trump Stumbles Over the Word ‘Yosemite’ During Bill Signing
description: During a routine bill signing of the Great American Outdoors Act, President Trump appeared to pronounce Yosemite as “Yo Semites.”
content: During a routine bill signing of the Great American Outdoors Act, President Trump appeared to pronounce Yosemite as “Yo Semites.”
